STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 11, 2025
Katherine Page-Sander
Hands Across The Water
781 Avis Dr. Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI, 48108-8959
RE: License#: CB810201161
Dear Ms. Page-Sander:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 6/30/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Group Organization: Hands Across The Water, Inc.
Licensee Designee: Katherine Page-Sander
Chief Administrator: Katherine Page-Sander
Name of Agency: Hands Across The Water
Agency Address: 781 Avis Dr. Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-8959

Original Issuance Date: 02/12/1999
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, International
Adoption, Place children for adoption, Place
children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
One of eight foster care files did not document all of the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
One of eight foster care files did not document all of the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:

(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside
in the foster home as provided in federal law.
One of eight foster care files did not document all of the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
One of eight foster care files did not document all of the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of eight foster care files did not document all of the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
Two of eight foster care files did not have an abbreviated service plan completed
within 30 days of case acceptance.

CPA Rule 400.12602 Program statement
(3) An agency shall document that the statement was
provided to all persons making inquiry about the
agency's services.
One of three adoption case records did not document the program statement was
provided to the applicant.
CPA Rule 400.12603 Policy and procedures
(2) An agency shall document that the policies and
procedures were provided to all persons making inquiry
about the agency's services.
One of three adoption records did not have documentation the policies and
procedures were reviewed and provided to the applicant.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of three adoption assessments was not completed in the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/20/24 Interim, CAP approved 1/3/25
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Development of Service Plans- The agency was provided with examples of
30-day abbreviated service plans that can be used to meet the rule
requirement when receiving a transferred case from another agency.
• Adoptive Family Evaluation- The agency was advised that in order to meet
the requirement to complete an adoption home study within 90 days of
application, the assessment can indicate no recommendation could be made
at that time and outline the information still needed in order to make a
recommendation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was required or requested.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency interim inspection was completed on 11/20/24, with the CAP
approved on 1/3/25. The agency was cited regarding special evaluatons and
adoption family evaluations. The agency reported successful implementation of
the CAP. However, the agency noted ongoing difficulty completing timely adoption
evaluations, due to applicants not completing requirements within the timeframes
given. This was evident in one repeat violation found for the 2025 review.
Technical Assistance was provided to the agency regarding this rule.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator (CA) assessment dated 6/4/2025 was reviewed on-site.
The CA reported the agency was able to implement the CAP from the 2024 review
with success, except for difficulty completing adoptive family evaluations timely.
The agency was provided with TA in that area, as well as recent policy update that
should help improve compliance over the next review period. Regarding disrupted
placements, the agency reported five unplanned moves. Four youth were removed
from an unlicensed relative placement due to substantiated concerns by DHHS.
One youth moved from an unlicensed relative placement, due to the relative
passing away unexpectedly. The CA reported the agency has grown over the past
year and accepted several new cases, which resulted in hiring new staff.
However, maintaining stable staffing continues to be struggling at times. The CA
reported the agency has received a grant from the Michigan Health Endowment
Fund, for projects to proactively address recruitment and retention of child welfare
staff. The agency reported systemic challenges that make foster care work
difficult. Challenges include a lack of adequate mental health service availability,
lack of affordable housing for clients, court inefficiencies causing adoption delays,
and expectations of court which are outside of the scope of typical foster care
work. However, the agency continues to maintain a high level of performance,
due to the dedication of long-time staff and leadership. The agency consistently
maintains Key Performance Indicators at 95-100%.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted the 12/31/24 financial audit and 2025 budget for review. No
financial concerns were noted.

Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. One staff reported being with the agency for
less than a year. They stated their experience has been great and they had an
excellent support system. The staff said they have learned a lot from everyone at
the agency and feel they are able to easily communicate with supervisors and
administrative staff. The second staff had been with the agency for over a year.
The staff stated they felt very supported, recognized, seen and heard. Staff stated
their supervisor was the best one they ever had and provides a level of support
never received in previous jobs. Staff stated that the job can be stressful at times,
but administration is good at recognizing this and showing appreciation. Neither
staff had concerns or suggestions of improvements.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as in previous years.
The office has ample space for staff and clients. There is sufficient meeting and
visitation space. The office has locked storage for files and confidential
information.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1: During a visit on 4/4/25, the relative caregiver’s home was missing
smoke detectors in the basement, 1st and 2nd floors. In addition, there was a light
blanket in the baby’s crib.
Resolution #1: The agency was advised of the safety alert on 4/7/25. Smoke
detectors were installed on all floors and the caseworker reviewed Safe Sleep with
the relative caregivers. Photos of the smoke detectors were provided to DCWL to
verify compliance.
Safety Alert #2: During a visit at a licensed foster home on 4/3/25, it was observed
that a smoke detector was missing from the basement.
Resolution #2: The agency was advised of the safety alert on 4/4/25. The agency
opened a special evaluation and made immediate contact with the foster parent. The
agency purchased a smoke detector and had it delivered to the foster home. The
foster parent sent a photo of the installed alarm to the agency on 4/8/25.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
_ ___________July 11, 2025_________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
